School of Chemical Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology Shanghai 200237 PR China Carbon dioxide (CO2) hydrogenation to aromatics is promising for reducing the burden of petroleum fuels. Herein, iron-based catalyst was mixed with boron modified HZSM-5 with pre-treatment and post-treatment method. The textural, acidic and element distribution properties over zeolite framework and external surface were studied. Combining with characterizations for internal and external coke, the element distribution-acidity-coke-stability relationship over boron-modified zeolite was put forward. Pre-treated zeolite witnessed reduced amount of external and total Brönsted acid sites (BAS) with similar degree, and increase paired Al (Alpair) fraction in the intersection site, leading to increased aromatics selectivity and reduced coke amount. While boron post-treatment significantly reduced external surface BAS and inhibited formation of condensed external coke. Afterwards, the mechanism of olefins aromatization was studied and found that PT-Z5-B greatly suppressed the overalkylation of light aromatics, thus alleviating the co-deactivation pattern generated by transformation of coke precursors from zeolite to iron-based catalyst. Graphical Abstract Keywords CO2 hydrogenation Aromatics Iron-based Boron modification Co-deactivation Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Carbon dioxide (CO2) conversion to value-added aromatics and aviation kerosene could not only alleviate the global demand for fossil fuel, but also decrease the emission of CO2 as greenhouse gas, which could cause global warming and ocean acidification, conforming well to the carbon neutrality and carbon peak concept [1,2]. Thermo-catalysis for CO2 hydrogenation to aromatics and aviation kerosene was widely studied and implemented on bifunctional catalyst composing of metal oxide catalyst and MFI type zeolites such as HZSM-5 (OX-ZEO strategy) to realize precise shape-selective C-C coupling to produce expected hydrocarbons [3,4]. Based on the different reaction route according to the intermediates including methanol and light olefins, the CO2-methanol-mediated route and modified CO2-FTS route were proved to be accessible for aromatics production while the former was subject to low CO2 conversion (< 20 %) and C5+ aliphatic hydrocarbons selectivity despite high aromatics selectivity [5]. CO2-FTS route was commonly featured by high CO2 conversion (> 40 %) along with impressive selectivity for aromatics and C5+ aliphatic hydrocarbons, while selectivity for CH4 as by-product could be substantially inhibited [6]. In addition, the combination of iron-based catalyst with indispensable alkali metal decoration enables efficient CO2 activation to form CO and light hydrocarbons for further C-C oligomerization, cyclization and hydrogen transfer process over acid sites in HZSM-5 pores [7,8]. Nevertheless, inevitable deactivation caused by coke formation could occur over the tandem catalyst for CO2-FTS route [9]. For the iron oxide catalyst, especially, higher chain growth probably (α) for C-C coupling, compared with nickel-based catalyst [10], was obtained based on a statistical distribution known as the Anderson-Schulz-Flory (ASF) distribution [11]. Besides, the products of the FTS were almost exclusively linear hydrocarbons, with isomerization existing in a separate process. The carbon filaments which grew rapidly may destroy the catalyst particles, leading to the loss of exposed active sites, and cause reactor plugging [10]. For the zeolites, coke deposition induced by unrestricted and irregular growth of carbon fibers could not only cover the active sites, but also block the pores for intermediates diffusion and conversion on the acid sites in zeolite channels, and hinder the further aromatization process. Thus, alleviating the coke deposition for both iron-based catalysts and zeolites is of great significance to extend catalyst life and reduce cost, especially for industrial application. However, the study for coke resistance were more concentrated over olefins oligomerization, methanol aromatization and paraffins dehydro-aromatization, which mainly applied sole zeolites as catalysts rather than bifunctional catalysts for the OX-ZEO strategy [12–14], while the coke study in tandem catalysis was rarely reported. Lee and co-workers studied the nature of internal and external coke in methanol to hydrocarbons reaction, and found that the comparative extension of alkene and arene based cycle in the micropores of zeolites decided the formation of methylated benzene as coke precursors, which led to the formation of internal coke [15]. Besides, He and co-workers believed that external coke, which could be generated by the deep hydrogen transfer and condensation between coke precursors and unsaturated hydrocarbons over external Brönsted acid sites (BAS), had less influence on the catalytic performance of n-hexene cracking than internal coke, and the external coke could be fully retained after hydrogen treatment at high temperature, by removing the less condensed internal coke [16]. However, some studies posted the deterioration effect of external coke by blocking the pore mouth, thus hindering the diffusion of reaction intermediates and coke precursors, causing fast catalyst deactivation [17,18]. Therefore, discovering the nature of internal and external coke, as well as figuring out their influence on catalyst deactivation is meaningful for the tandem catalysis of CO2 hydrogenation. Nevertheless, merely considering the deactivation process over zeolites could not summarize and probe the deactivation mechanism of the whole bifunctional catalyst. Therefore, exploring the correlation of deactivation between the two components is of great significance to improve the stability of bifunctional catalysts. Besides, putting forward the coking pattern and searching methods for coke alleviation is of great significance for future industrial application of CO2 hydrogenation to aromatics via OX-ZEO route. Boron modification over zeolites, especially on HZSM-5, has been widely applied for oxidative dehydrogenation for propane, but rarely implemented for bifunctional catalysts. Xiao and co-workers found that isolated boron species formed over boron-containing MFI type zeolite, which served for oxygen activation, could dramatically enhance the catalyst stability by hindering the hydrolysis of active boron species [19]. Lu and co-workers observed the mobility nature of aggregated boron species, increasing the dispersion of oligomeric boron and promoting the catalyst stability [20]. These researches focused on the direct impact of boron species as active sites, while the influence of boron modification on the zeolite acidity and element distribution, which acted as the main factor for coke deposition and catalyst stability of zeolites, deserved further research. Herein, boron modification was carried out over phase transfer HZSM-5 to study its influence on textural, acidic properties and microscopic element distribution of the zeolites through a series of characterizations. Combining with the coke analysis over internal and external coke, the element distribution-acidity-coke-stability relationship over boron-modified zeolite was put forward. The mechanism of olefins aromatization was also studied and found that PT-Z5-B greatly suppressed the overalkylation of light aromatics. Finally, the co-deactivation pattern generated by transformation of aromatic coke precursors from zeolite to iron-based catalyst was proposed. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalysts preparation 2.1.1 Preparation of iron-based catalyst The Cu and Na decorated iron-based catalyst (NFC-DM) was prepared by pyrolysis of Cu-doped double metal organic framework MIL-101(Fe) according to our previous paper [21]. 2.1.2 Preparation of zeolites PT-Z5 zeolite was synthesized using a phase transfer method [22]. In the precursor solution, tetrapropylammonium hydroxide (TPAOH) was used as the template. Besides, toluene (T) and trimethoxysilyl [3-(phenylamino)propyl] silane (TPPS) was added as structure-directing agents. The molar ratio of the reactants in the precursor solution was: TPAOH: Al2O3: SiO2: H2O: Na2O: T: TPPS = 20: 2: 100: 2500: 4: 500: 5. Firstly, specific proportion of sodium hydroxide, aluminum isopropoxide (AIP), and TPAOH were completely dissolved in deionized water under continuous stirring to ensure a homogeneous solution. Afterwards, tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS), T, and TPPS were sequentially added dropwise to this solution, and the mixture was further stirred for 2 h to allow sufficient mixing. Subsequently, the obtained solution was transferred to a high-pressure reactor and rotated for crystallization at 170 ℃ for 48 h at 45 rpm. After crystallization, the product was separated from the solution using centrifugation. The separated product was washed several times with ethanol and deionized water until the supernatant reached a neutral state. The product was then dried overnight at 110 ℃ and calcined at 550 ℃ under fluent air for 5 h to obtain the Na-type ZSM-5 zeolite. Finally, the Na-ZSM-5 zeolite was converted into HZSM-5 through ion exchange in 1 M NH4Cl solution (ratio of 20 ml/g) at a constant temperature of 80 °C for 3 h. This process was repeated three times to ensure complete ion exchange. After this step, the product was centrifuged and washed using the aforementioned method. Then, the product was dried overnight again at 110 ℃ and calcined at 550 ℃ for 4 h to obtain PT-Z5 zeolite. The preparation method of B-PT-Z5 zeolite (pre-treatment) was similar to that of PT-Z5, except that boric acid (H3BO3) was added simultaneously with AIP, with a feed molar ratio of TPAOH: Al2O3: H3BO3: SiO2: H2O: Na2O: T:TPPS = 40: 3: 2: 200: 5000: 8: 1000: 10. The remaining synthesis and subsequent purification operations were identical to those of PT-Z5. PT-Z5-B was prepared via impregnation method (post-treatment) based on PT-Z5. Typically, specific amount of boric acid was dissolved in deionized water to prepare a 10 ml boric acid solution. Then, 5 g of the prepared PT-Z5 was impregnated with the H3BO3 solution. The mixture was placed at ambient condition for 24 h. Subsequently, the product was dried at 110 ℃ overnight and finally calcined in air at 550 ℃ for 5 h to obtain PT-Z5-B. Co2+ ions balanced zeolite samples were prepared to study the Al siting in the zeolite framework [13]. Typically, the as-synthesized H-type samples were renewedly ion-exchanged with 1 M NaCl solution for three times at 80 °C for 5 h, in order to obtain Na-type zeolites. Afterwards, the Na-type zeolites were ion-exchanged with 0.05 M Co(NO3)2 solution for three times at 80 °C for 8 h to get the zeolite samples with Co2+ ions balanced. Finally, the samples were centrifugated and dried at 110 ℃ overnight. Commercial HZSM-5 was bought from Nankai University and named as C-Z5. 2.2 Catalysts test CO2 hydrogenation experiments were implemented in a 316 L stainless fixed-bed reactor with a 10 mm tube diameter from Shanghai Yanzheng Experimental Instrument Co., Ltd. (YZμBPR-G3-L1-B). All catalysts were crushed and sieved into 40–60 mesh before reaction. For the 120 h long-term stability test, typically, 0.5 g oxide and 0.5 g zeolite were mixed to obtain bifunctional catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation. The catalysts were set in the constant temperature section without diluent. All the catalysts underwent reduction process under a 40 % H2/N2 flow (100 ml/min) at 320 ℃ for 10 h at ambient pressure. Afterwards, the reaction gas (CO2/H2/N2=24/72/4) with an inlet flow rate of 50 ml/min was pumped into the fixed bed and the reaction system was gradually inflated to 3 MPa and the stability test was carried out. For CO2 hydrogenation test over the spent iron oxides, 0.5 g of catalysts were applied and the flow rate was set to be 25 ml/min. The gaseous products were monitored by an online Agilent 7890B gas chromatograph loaded with a thermal conductor detector (TCD) for analyzing CH4, N2, CO and CO2. while the flame ionization detector (FID) was operated to separate and detect C2-C4 hydrocarbons. The liquid products were condensed by a cold trap to separate heavy hydrocarbons and analyzed by PerkinElmer Clarus 580 gas chromatograph. These detections were carried out every 12 h during the stability test of CO2 hydrogenation while the products of CO2 hydrogenation over spent oxides were detected at 8 h of time of stream (TOS). 2.3 Calculation method The calculation methods involved in this paper are listed as follows: CO2 conversion is calculated by: X r = n r 0 − n r n r 0 × 100 % , r = C O 2 Where n r 0 and n r are molar quantities of CO2 in the feed stock and effluent during the reaction. Selectivity of the generated hydrocarbons is calculated by: S i = m × n i , m n r 0 − n r × 100 % Where n i , m is the molar quantity of the generated hydrocarbon i while m is the number of carbons in one molecular [22]. 2.4 Catalysts characterization Detail explanation of catalyst characterization is presented in the Supporting Information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the zeolites 3.1.1 Textural properties The powder XRD spectra of PT-Z5, B-PT-Z5 and PT-Z5-B are presented in Fig. 1 a. All the samples displayed typical diffraction patterns of HZSM-5 with MFI type morphology, as evidenced by the diffraction peaks located at 7.9°, 9.0°, 14.7° and 23.1° [23]. No phase belonging to impurities were detected over the zeolites. Besides, the XRD peak intensity decrease in the following trend: PT-Z5 > PT-Z5-B > B-PT-Z5, indicating the highest crystallinity of PT-Z5, as also confirmed by Scherrer equation calculation based on XRD diffraction peak at 7.9° and (011) lattice plane (Table S1). The decreased crystallinity of B-PT-Z5 could be explained by the isomorphically embedding of boron into the zeolite framework with higher difficulty compare with aluminum, leading to a more defective morphology [24]. While for PT-Z5-B, it could be attributed to the dealumination and structure destruction caused by the impregnation of acidic H3BO3 solution [21]. Fig. 3 b displayed the FT-IR spectra of the fresh zeolites. The unique peak located at around 930 cm−1 could be attributed to the stretching vibrations of the Si-O-B moiety in the B-PT-Z5 catalysts [20], which could hardly be detected for the other samples, further confirming the incorporation of boron atoms into zeolite framework for B-PT-Z5. Besides, the area between 730 cm−1 to 1400 cm−1 is featured by SiO4 tetrahedra [25], whose intensity witness obvious reduction in B-PT-Z5 but comparative for PT-Z5 and PT-Z5-B, indicating the pre-treatment of boron inhibited the crystallization process of B-PT-Z5, resulting in a more fragmented structure with less existence of complete SiO4 tetrahedra. Table S1 also listed the B/Al and Si/Al ratio of the zeolites. Approximate Si/Al was obtained for PT-Z5 and PT-Z5-B, while higher value was observed for B-PT-Z5, which could be generated by the competition of B and Al insertion into the framework T sites, also leading to a decreased B/Al ratio in B-PT-Z5 compared with PT-Z5-B prepared by direct impregnation of boron acid solution. Fig. 1 b, c displayed the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distribution for the phase transfer zeolites. All samples exhibited type Ⅰ isotherms with H4 type hysteresis loops, indicating the micropores-dominated pore structure with the partial mediation of mesopores [26]. Table S1 listed the relevant BET parameters for the zeolites. PT-Z5-B presented comparative BET surface area with slightly increased content of micropore surface area and slight decrease of external surface area, compared with PT-Z5. Thus, post-treatment of boron species had little influence on zeolite textural properties. For B-PT-Z5, however, appreciable increase of BET surface area was observed despite the constant micropore surface area, indicating that the content of mesopores increased via pre-treatment by boron species, which could also be confirmed by the increase of average pore size to 3.16 nm. Figure S1 displayed the SEM images and particle distribution of zeolites, which could reveal the influence of pre- and post- treatment by boron species on the textural properties and particle size. All samples exhibited irregular sphere morphology with rough surface. However, B-PT-Z5 displayed smaller particle size compared with PT-Z5 while PT-Z5-B showed the inverse trend, as confirmed by the particle size distribution (Figure S1) and the corresponding average particle size (Table S1). The observed smallest particle size for B-PT-Z5 (339 nm) agree well with the calculated smallest crystal size by Scherrer equation. Fig. 2 and Figure S2 displayed the SEM and EDS element mapping of PT-Z5-B and B-PT-Z5, illustrating the uniform distribution of Si, Al and B, which indicate that both boron-modification methods were incapable of causing partial boron aggregation. 3.1.2 Acidity properties Acidity properties of the zeolite samples were characterized by NH3-TPD, Py-IR, DTBPy-IR and FT-IR ( Fig. 3) and the detail acid amount was listed in Table S2. According to the NH3-TPD spectra (Fig. 3 a), all zeolite samples presented two major desorption area. The peaks located at lower temperature (100–200 ℃) were attributed to the weak acid sites while higher temperature peaks at 300–500 ℃ were assigned to the strong acid sites, which could represent the Brönsted acid sites (BAS) [27]. According to Table S2, post-treatment of boron impregnation slightly increased the amount of weak acid sites with an obvious decrease in strong acid sites. Moreover, the peak belonging to strong acid sites shifts to lower temperature in NH3-TPD image, indicating the less intensified strength for strong acid sites. Besides, the pre-treatment by boron acid led to both decrease of weak and strong acid sites in B-PT-Z5, while the peak temperature shifted to lowest location among the zeolites, suggesting that the acid strength and amount were both significantly suppressed. Fig. 3 b representing the FT-IR spectra of fresh zeolites further demonstrated the highest acidity for PT-Z5 by showing the most intensified peak at around 3500 cm−1, which belonged to the -OH species for BAS [21], while the lowest intensity was observed for B-PT-Z5. In addition, Py-IR was carried out to monitor the total and strong BAS and Lewis acid site (LAS) at 150 ℃ and 350 ℃, respectively. As illustrated from Fig. 3 c and Figure S3, the peak located at 1545 cm−1 and 1455 cm−1 are assigned to BAS and LAS [28]. The amount of total and strong BAS/LAS are listed in Table S2. PT-Z5 exhibited highest total BAS and LAS amount, with the decrease of both acid amount and B/L ratio after boron modification. Compared with PT-Z5, strong BAS amount decreases from 67 μmol/g to 34 μmol/g and 41 μmol/g for B-PT-Z5 and PT-Z5-B, respectively, fitting well with the declined amount of strong acid sites in NH3-TPD results. Conversely, strong LAS amount slightly increases in B-PT-Z5 and dramatically increases to 37 μmol/g for PT-Z5-B. Thus, lowest strong B/L ratio of 1.1 was obtained over PT-Z5-B, which could be resulted from dealumination by treatment of boron acid solution, leading to increased content of AlEF acting as surface LAS [21,29,30]. Besides, the impregnated boron species at external surface could also act as strong LAS because of the electron donating ability for the tri-coordinated boron atom. For DTBPy-IR spectra (Fig. 3 d), the intense peaks located at ∼1615 cm−1 represent strong external BAS [31]. PT-Z5 possesses highest ratio of strong external BAS in the total strong BAS, fitting well with the FT-IR results, while PT-Z5-B only occupies half of its value, suggesting that the external BAS was significantly suppressed after impregnation of boron acid. For B-PT-Z5, strong external BAS fraction in total strong BAS was comparative to that of PT-Z5, indicating that boron occupation into zeolite framework and external surface possessed approximate possibility, thus decreasing BAS amount in a similar degree. In summary, boron pre-treatment could simultaneously suppress internal and external BAS amount while significantly reduce the acid strength. While boron post-treatment only slightly influenced total acidity while greatly inhibited the external acidity. Besides, both treatments decreased the B/L ratio in the zeolites. 3.1.3 Investigation of the element siting in zeolites Atom distribution in the zeolite channels and surface would greatly influence the catalytic performance and stability. In order to further investigate the microcosmic distribution of Al species at different chemical position, DR UV–vis of Co(Ⅱ) ions balanced zeolite samples were carried out and presented in Fig. 4 and Table S3. As was reported by Dedecek, the Co(Ⅱ) ions could interact with the Al atoms that are close enough in the ZSM-5 framework by balancing the two negative charges, while the corresponding Al atoms were named as Alpair and those Al atoms with long distance that could not coordinate with Co(Ⅱ) ions were defined as Aliso [32]. After deconvolution of the DR UV–vis spectra at a range from 13,000 cm−1 to 23,000 cm−1 which implied the aggregation of different Al siting that coordinated with the d-d band transitions of Co2+ ions, seven major peaks assigned to three peak area were obtained for all the samples. In detail, the peak located at 15300 cm−1 represents the Co2+ ions coordinated in the in the straight channels (α); The peaks located at 16,200, 17,100, 18,500 and 21,000 cm−1 are attributed to the Co2+ ions balanced in the intersection sites (β) and the peaks at 20,000 and 22,000 cm−1 are attributed to the Co2+ ions in the sinusoidal channels (γ) [13]. As presented in Table S3, decrease of the content of Alpair is observed in the boron-containing samples compared with PT-Z5, while B-PT-Z5 showed the lowest value of 54 % Alpair, suggesting the prolonged distance of adjacent Al atom during the formation of zeolite framework due to the competition of B and Al atoms. While the slight decrease of Alpair in PT-Z5-B could be explained by the slight dealumination of zeolite framework during the impregnation process. Alpair are widely acknowledged to produce stronger acidity than Aliso [33]. Thus, the trend for acid strength obtained from previous section agreed well with the Alpair content in zeolites. Moreover, the impregnation method of boron species could hardly influence the β site content, but only slightly enhances the α site content, indicating that the dealumination process was prior to occur in the sinusoidal channels (γ). However, a drastic increase of Alpair in β site was witnessed for B-PT-Z5 compared with PT-Z5, with the simultaneous decrease in γ site content, suggesting that the Al atoms in the γ site are easier to be substituted by boron atoms compared with the β site, generating concentrated Alpair species with stronger acidity in the intersection site. Besides, 27Al MAS NMR was applied to investigate the Al species located at different positions and T sites. As illustrated in Fig. 5 a and Table S4, two major peaks could be detected between −20–20 ppm for all the zeolites samples, representing the framework Al species (AlF) at 55 ppm and the extra framework Al (AlEF) at 0 ppm, respectively [21]. After the modification of boron species using different methods, the AlF peak intensity drastically decrease for B-PT-Z5 and PT-Z5-B, indicating the reduction of Al atoms in the framework, which could probably be caused by the competition of B and Al atoms for constructing the Si-OH-Al(B) function groups in the framework, and the dealumination of framework Al due to the impregnation of aqueous boron acid solution, respectively. PT-Z5-B obtained the highest AlEF content of 20 % among all the zeolites, indicating that the dealumination process caused the enrichment of AlEF species over the external surface by extracting the internal AlF from zeolite framework. In addition, Fig. 5 b-d illustrated the deconvoluted peaks of paired AlF species for all zeolite samples. Typically, all the peaks were separated into four secondary peaks located at 49, 53, 56 and 59 ppm. Peaks at 49 and 53 ppm are related to Al species at T1-T3, T5-T7, T9 and T12 sites in the intersection sites (β), while peaks located at 56 and 59 ppm correspond to T4, T8, T10 and T11 sites in the straight channels with 10-MRs (α) [24,34]. As is shown in Table S4, the fraction of 49 ppm dramatically increases in B-PT-Z5 with the decrease of 53 ppm. Meanwhile, the fraction of 56 ppm also decreases with the slight increase in 59 ppm. However, the total fraction of Al species in the intersection sites increases in B-PT-Z5, fitting well with the UV–vis spectra. Compared with B-PT-Z5, PT-Z5-B displayed comparative total Al content for α and β site after impregnation method, despite the significant variation of the relative content for 49 and 53 ppm, also indicating that boron impregnation barely influenced the AlF distribution. 29Si MAS NMR was further carried out to study the Al and Si siting in the zeolite samples. As is exhibited in Fig. 6 and Table S5, the peaks range from −90 to −125 ppm were further deconvoluted to six secondary peaks corresponding to different framework Si (Fig. 6 b-d). Peaks located at −110, −113, −115 and −118 ppm are related to Si atoms at T6+T12, T9+T11, T8+T10 and T1-T5 sites, which are tetrahedrally coordinated with the adjacent Si atoms, denoting as Q4 sites (Si(0Al)). Besides, the peak at −113 ppm is attributed to the crystallographic inequivalent Q4 sites [35]. Two peaks located at −103 and −105 ppm could be assigned to Si atoms in tetrahedral coordination with adjacent aluminum atoms, whose resonances could be nominated as Q3 sites (Si(1Al)), and is generally acknowledged as BAS in the zeolites [12]. The fraction of Q3 sites witnessed an obvious decrease in B-PT-Z5, but is not so distinct in PT-Z5-B, indicating the inhibition of BAS after boron modification, agreeing well with the Py-IR and FT-IR results. Figure S4 displayed the 11B MAS NMR spectra for B-PT-Z5 and PT-Z5-B. B-PT-Z5 displayed a strong peak located from −10–0 ppm, which could be assigned to the tetrahedrally coordinated boron (B[4]) sites at the TO4 site of the zeolite framework. Besides, the weak peak ranged from 0 to 10 ppm with a peak center at 5 ppm was related to tri-coordinated boron species (B[3]) over the zeolite external surface (eg. BO(SiO)2). Moreover, the tiny peak from 10 to 15 ppm could be attributed to extra-framework boron species which was close to silanol and H2O, for example, the B(OB)x(OH)3-x (x = 1, 2) species [19,20,24]. The stronger peak for (B[4]) sites in B-PT-Z5 indicated the partial substitution of boron for the Al atoms in the framework with a tetra-coordination state, acting as weaker BAS compared with AlO4. However, PT-Z5-B displayed stronger intensity for boron species over zeolite external surface and extra-framework, probably caused by the impregnation process. The external or extra-framework boron species could substitute the external BAS, leading to reduced surface acidity. 3.1.4 Relationship between zeolite acidity and element distribution The relationship between zeolite acidity and element distribution is illustrated in Scheme 1. PT-Z5 without modification presented highest BAS amount and intensity, while the 27Al NMR indicated the dominance of framework Al compared with AlEF, suggesting that acidity in PT-Z5 was mainly provided by Si-OH-Al function group relating with tetrahedral AlO4 species in the framework. Besides, the highest calculated Alpair content further confirmed the highest acidity of PT-Z5, as adjacent Al pairs could provide stronger acidity than isolated Al. The Alpair distribution in PT-Z5 mainly located in γ and β site with an (α+γ)/β ratio of 0.8. For B-PT-Z5, comparatively, significant loss of acid amount and intensity was observed with a drastic decrease in B/L ratio. Besides, the amount of external BAS decreased while its fraction in total BAS remained constant. The decreased Alpair indicated less intensified acid strength for B-PT-Z5, probably because of the dominant alteration of B atoms for Al atoms at γ site in the zeolite framework, constructing tetrahedral BO4 sites with Si-OH-B function group that provided weaker acidity than Al. Therefore, Alpair species was concentrated at β site, generating more BAS active sites at the intersection area. The increased LAS content could be explained by the appearance of tri-coordinated boron species over the zeolite external surface. For PT-Z5-B, slightly lower total acidity was achieved as PT-Z5, despite the slight decrease in the amount strong acid sites and BAS, with a drastic increase in LAS, which was generated by dealumination process, creating more AlEF species and the external/extra-framework boron species acting as LAS. Besides, surface BAS content was significantly suppressed by surface boron modification. In spite of the decrease in Alpair content caused by dealumination, the Alpair distribution in different area of framework was hardly influenced. 3.2 Stability test for CO2 hydrogenation The zeolite samples were granule-mixed with NFC-DM and applied for 120 h stability test of CO2 hydrogenation to aromatics at 320 ℃, 3Mpa and a GHSV of 3000 ml·gcat −1·h−1. Fig. 7 displayed the stability test results for PT-Z5, B-PT-Z5, PT-Z5-B, while C-Z5 was also evaluated as reference at a constant condition. At the initial 12 h, PT-Z5 presented highest CO2 conversion of 45.6 % among the phase transfer zeolites, contrasting with 40.1 % for B-PT-Z5 and 43.7 % for PT-Z5-B. However, despite the highest CO2 conversion of 47.2 %, aromatics selectivity displayed lowest value for C-Z5 with the decreasing trend: B-PT-Z5 (52.6 %) > PT-Z5 (48.0 %) > PT-Z5-B (46.9 %) > C-Z5 (37.3 %). Considering the same oxide catalyst and reaction conditions applied in the tests, the zeolite acidity properties would determine the reaction performance at early stage. The lowest aromatics selectivity for C-Z5 could be explained that the high content of extra-framework Al of 59 % in total Al species detected by NMR (Figure S5), which acted as the source of surface LAS, led to high LAS/BAS ratio, favoring oligomerization over external surface rather than aromatization in the zeolite pores [36]. Similar trend could be observed over PT-Z5-B, which presented lowest B/L ratio and highest C5+ selectivity among phase transfer zeolites. For B-PT-Z5, however, the highest aromatics selectivity at the initial stage could be explained by the concentrated Alpair fraction in the intersection site, thus favoring the arene cycle and producing more aromatics [24]. It should be mentioned that PT-Z5 without modification displayed highest C2-C4 paraffins selectivity along with lowest C5+ selectivity. This could be explained by its strongest acidity, thus leading to the excessive hydrogenation of light olefins into paraffins, losing its activity for further C-C coupling [22]. Besides, Figure S6 displayed the trend of BTEX selectivity in liquid phase during the stability test. At 12 h time on stream, PT-Z5-B showed distinctively highest BTEX selectivity in liquid phase (22.7 %) compared with the other zeolites. This could be confirmed by the suppressed surface BAS amount provided by boron modification. The aromatics formed in the channels and intersection area would undergo less alkylation when diffusing to the zeolite channels [37]. While the lowest value for C-Z5 (12.0 %) indicated the distinct capability for aromatics alkylation over the significant external BAS. As the reaction proceeded to 120 h of TOS, CO2 conversion and aromatics selectivity all witnessed inevitable reduction for all the samples, which was attributed to the co-operative coke-induced catalyst deactivation over iron-based catalysts and zeolites. PT-Z5 presented 26.2 % CO2 conversion loss at 48 h TOS and remain stable, indicating the fastest deactivation route. And the value for B-PT-Z5 and PT-Z5-B was 11.4 % and 2.0 %, respectively. The slowest rate of CO2 conversion loss for PT-Z5-B indicated that boron modification endowed the iron-based catalyst with fabulous coke-resisting ability. As CO2 conversion are strongly related with the surface activation behavior over Fe-based catalyst, it was suggested that the deactivation of NFC-DM component in the tandem catalyst were indirectly alleviated by boron modification over PT-Z5-B. Besides, all gaseous products underwent varying degree of increase for all zeolite samples. For the integrally decreased liquid phase selectivity, nevertheless, C5+ selectivity displayed different trend for the phase transfer zeolites with slight fluctuation while aromatics selectivity presented decrease trend. Meanwhile, aromatics selectivity loss for the zeolites after 120 h TOS decreased as: PT-Z5 (54.0 %) > B-PT-Z5 (46.9 %) > PT-Z5-B (41.2 %), indicating different pattern and extent for the inhibition of boron modification over coke-induced deactivation for zeolites. Besides, no alcohols or aldehydes were detected in the reaction period. Figure S13 illustrating the B 1S XPS spectra confirmed the existence of more stable boron species in B-PT-Z5 rather than PT-Z5-B. Overall, the deactivation pattern for the tandem catalyst was reflected by the diverging deactivation degree of iron oxide according to the CO2 conversion loss, along with the zeolite deactivation confirmed by loss of aromatics selectivity. Thus, coke analysis and characterization over the spent oxide and zeolite samples were further implemented to get deep insight of the deactivation nature. 3.3 Coke analysis over zeolites Coke formation over the zeolites was studied respectively using various strategies. TG analysis was implemented for quantification of deposited coke on spent zeolites after 120 h stability test. As illustrated in Figure S7, the highest coke amount was observed over spent PT-Z5, followed by PT-Z5-B and B-PT-Z5. The coke amount for the spent zeolites were 39, 18 and 27 mg/gcat for PT-Z5, B-PT-Z5 and PT-Z5-B. Moreover, XRD of spent zeolite (Figure S8) indicated the same trend of crystallinity as the fresh zeolites, and no characteristic peak for condensed coke was observed. Actually, coke formation with different type and location is strongly related to the distribution and diffusion of coke intermediates in zeolite channels and external surface, that is to say, higher concentration of coke precursors with intensified acidic atmosphere and scarce spatial confinement would result in more condensed coke formation caused by the hydrogen transfer reaction between coke precursors and olefins. For the zeolite samples, highest strong BAS amount on PT-Z5 resulted in significant hydrogen transfer reaction. Besides, highest content of strong external BAS generated sterically unlimited growth and dehydrogenation of coke precursors, thus favoring the formation of heavy coke at the external surface [15]. For PT-Z5-B, the suppressed strong external BAS amount would lead to less hydrogen transfer between the coke precursors that diffuse to the external surface with olefins, leading to inhibited external coke formation. For B-PT-Z5, the total reduced BAS amount inhibited the total coke amount, and the enlarged pore size combining with the contractible particle size (leading to decreased diffusion path for coke intermediates) allowed the well-off transformation of coke precursors to the outer surface rather than being captured by the active sites for deep coking. Figure S9 presented the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms for the spent zeolites, while the BET parameters were listed in Table S6. The BET surface area witnessed significant loss for SP-PT-Z5 with the simultaneous decrease in pore volume and external surface area, indicating both severe deactivation in the zeolite pores and external surface. Comparatively, deactivation for B-PT-Z5 was drastically alleviated as evidenced by the highest remained BET surface area and pore volume, indicating the lest coke formation over the spent zeolite, fitting well with the TG results. Besides, external surface area both witnessed significant reduction over SP-PT-Z5 and SP-B-PT-Z5 rather than SP-PT-Z-B, further confirming the inhibited external coke formation. In order to further understand the coke nature, TPO-MS was carried out ( Fig. 8). Fig. 8 a illustrated the TPO spectra, which depicted more obvious peaks for PT-Z5 than the other zeolites, fitting well with the highest coke amount over PT-Z5 in TG results. Fig. 8 b-d illustrated MS spectra for m/z = 28, 18 and 44, related with the signal of CO, H2O and CO2. The spectra of m/z = 44 could be roughly separated into two parts. The area below and beyond 450 ℃ could be attributed to different types of coke labelled as type Ⅰ and Ⅱ. Coke Ⅰ mainly accounted for the deposition of carbon fiber species (long chain aliphatics, light aromatics and alkylbenzene) inside the micropores of zeolites inflicted with the steric confinements, which is easier to be removed by combustion, while coke Ⅱ composed of the carbon deposits with more disorganized feature that grew towards outer surface of zeolite framework without the steric limitation of micropores (polyalkylbenzene, polyaromatics and graphite like coke) [38,39]. After deconvolution of the MS spectra for CO2, the content of different types of coke were listed in Table S6. Spent PT-Z5 not only exhibited highest total coke amount, but also possessed largest amount of coke Ⅱ, agreeing well with the highest acidity and strong external BAS content for PT-Z5, which facilitated the external coke formation, thus blocking the pore mouth for mass diffusion and isolating olefins intermediates from internal active sites, causing fast zeolite deactivation evidenced by fastest aromatics selectivity loss (Fig. 7 a). The content of coke Ⅱ dramatically decreased in B-PT-Z5, not only because of the suppressed external BAS amount, but also the decrease of total B/L ratio in the framework (Table S2), thereby facilitating the oligomerization and inhibiting the excessive hydrogen transfer to form condensed coke. Furthermore, the concentration of Alpair in β area facilitated the aromatization process in the intersection area, increasing the coke Ⅰ content in the zeolite channel. The lowest content of coke Ⅱ in PT-Z5-B could be explained by its lowest level of surface BAS amount. Moreover, C/H ratio of the coke could reveal its condensation extent. The C/H ratio of coke Ⅰ and coke Ⅱ was calculated based on the area of MS spectra respectively and listed in Table S6. Obvious trend could be deduced that coke Ⅰ presented lower C/H ratio than coke Ⅱ for all the samples, suggesting different condensed extent for inner and outer coke. Although strong external BAS content exhibited similar value for PT-Z5 and B-PT-Z5, the C/H value for PT-Z5 was far higher than B-PT-Z5. This could be explained by the decrease of external BAS amount and the increased Alpair in β site (with the decrease in γ site). The aromatics produced by enhanced aromatization produced in the intersection site would undergo less hydrogen transfer when diffusing through and out of zeolite channels, resulting in less condensed coke with decreased C/H ratio. Moreover, the unexpected low C/H ratio of coke Ⅰ in spent PT-Z5-B could be explained by the dehydration of extra-framework boron species [e.g., B(OH)3] with close silanol or (H2O)n, which was generated by hydration of H2O in the reaction system, during the TPO process [19]. The appearance of CO in the test could be explained by Boudouard reaction from deposit carbon and the generated CO2, which displayed similar trend with MS signal for CO2 [40]. Fig. 9 d illustrated the 13C MAS NMR of the spent zeolites. The chemical shift between 0 and 50 and 100–150 ppm belonged to the aliphatic and aromatic compounds [16]. Spent PT-Z5 exhibited highest intensity of both peak aera, further indicating the most severe deactivation among the zeolites. Besides, B-PT-Z5 displayed significantly weakened intensity for the two peaks with comparative extent, while PT-Z5-B showed more intensified peak for the aliphatic compound and obvious suppression for the aromatics peak. These observations further corroborated with the TPO-MS coke analysis, as PT-Z5-B possessed lowest coke Ⅱ amount, which mainly composed of heavy polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons and graphite like coke. Previous study has proved that H2 treatment for the deactivated zeolites could eliminate the soft and internal coke and retain the hard coke which mainly located at zeolite external surface [16]. Thus, in order to quantify the amount of internal and external coke with different condensation extent of spent zeolites, H2 treatment at 850 ℃ for 2 h was first carried out to remove the internal coke. The H2 regeneration process was characterized by TPH-MS, which was illustrated in Fig. 9. Fig. 9 a presented the TCD signal during the detection. Generally, the peaks could be separated into three area denoted as [α], [β], [γ] and the corresponding peak area was listed in Table S7. Area [α] with lower temperature peak could be attributed to the aliphatic carbon fibers generated at the zeolite straight and sinusoidal channels. Besides, area [β] could be attributed to the alkylbenzene and polyalkylbenzene compounds generated at both the intersection sites and the channels. Area [γ] were related to more polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, such as naphthalene and anthracene like compounds, which was considered as the major reason for deactivation in the zeolite framework [15]. B-PT-Z5 further presented higher area [γ] content and lower [β] area content compared with PT-Z5, indicating that the concentrated Alpair in the intersection area could accelerate polyaromatic like internal coke formation. Furthermore, PT-Z5-B displayed highest content of [α] area content, probably because of the highest LAS content favoring oligomerization and aliphatics formation. In addition, during the H2 treatment process, hydrogen was adsorbed and activated near the framework Al sites. And the internal coke interacted with residue BAS in the framework to form carbonium-ion transition state and then transformed into light hydrocarbons via mono-molecular cracking. The cracking process involved sequential hydrogenation of soft coke and dealkylation to realize the chain-length shortening. Thus, the H2 treatment for internal coke removing was also determined by the remained acidity in the spent catalyst [41]. Py-IR of spent zeolites (Figure S10 and Table S8) displayed highest remained BAS in PT-Z5-B, indicating the strongest cracking ability of soft coke, which could also be confirmed by the MS signal spectra of m/z = 16 (methane) and 30 (ethane) (Fig. 9 b-c), displaying the lowest temperature peak for PT-Z5-B with strongest coke elimination by H2 treatment. After the H2 treatment to remove the internal coke, TG analysis was carried out afterwards to quantify the external coke. As illustrated in Figure S11, the weight loss trend was similar to the zeolites without H2 treatment. The calculated content of external coke displayed highest value for SP-PT-Z5 without boron modification (Table S6), followed by SP-B-PT-Z5, while SP-PT-Z5-B only presented 52 % external coke, further revealing the anti-coke boron covering for inhibition of surface BAS. In conclusion, the element distribution-acidity-coke-stability relationship is elaborated as follows. PT-Z5 displayed highest content of Alpair and AlEF among the zeolites, endowing both strongest acidity in zeolite framework and external surface, which led to highest coke amount with the fastest aromatics selectivity loss. B-PT-Z5 showed decreased Alpair content and increased LAS amount. The substitution of boron atoms into external surface and framework simultaneously reduced internal and external BAS by comparative extent. Thereby, reduced total coke amount was witnessed. However, Alpair concentration in β site accelerated the arene cycle, which provided highest aromatics selectivity at initial stage and highest aromatics selectivity loss next only to PT-Z5, because of the polyaromatics coke formed in the zeolite channel. For PT-Z5-B, the external BAS was significantly suppressed with the existence of extra-framework boron species, leading to inhibited formation of external coke and highest BTEX selectivity. However, the surprising low CO2 conversion loss witnessed in PT-Z5-B still need more profound study. 3.4 Unveiling the deactivation pattern of zeolites by In-situ Drifts In order to further investigate the influence of boron modification over deactivation mechanism of phase transfer zeolites, In-situ DRIFTS applying C2H4 as the probe molecular over sole zeolites was carried out and illustrated in Fig. 10. Ethylene (10 % in nitrogen) feed gas was introduced into an in-situ cell at 320 ℃ and then tracked with DRIFTS. The peak area ranging from 2800 cm−1 to 3200 cm−1 was observed for all zeolites, which belong to the symmetrical and asymmetrical stretching vibrations of the CH3 and CH2 groups [42]. These C-H bands could be originated from gas-phase ethylene and ethane molecules adsorbed inside the zeolite channels, as well as hydrocarbon products generated by ethene oligomerization. In addition, the peaks at 1200 cm−1 and 1300 cm−1, which were also ascribed to the C-H stretching vibration of CH2 and CH3 groups [43]. Intensity of these peaks underwent gradual increase within 60 min time on stream. Besides, the peaks located greater than 3500 cm−1 represented the vibration of surface OH species from surface BAS. PT-Z5 exhibited highest intensity for BAS, fitting well with the FT-IR and Py-IR results, and slightly decreased during the test, indicating the prolonging catalyst deactivation over PT-Z5. Moreover, the peak area from 1400 to 1800 cm−1 presenting the CC vibration in hydrocarbons was detected and magnified in Fig. 10 d-f. The absorption band assigned to the ν (CC) of the benzene ring skeleton at 1500 cm−1 was observed along with the existence of a weak band at 3077 cm−1 assigning to the vibration of C-H band in the benzene ring, indicating the formation of aromatics on all the zeolites [42,44,45]. In addition, the peaks located at around 1560 cm−1, 1605 cm−1 and 1670 cm−1 in Fig. 10 d-f could be attributed to polyalkylated benzenes, highly unsaturated polyaromatics and CC band of oligomeric unsaturated hydrocarbons, respectively [42,46,47]. It could be concluded that PT-Z5 and B-PT-Z5 both presented visible peak for polyalkylated benzenes, which was unable to detect over PT-Z5-B, with PT-Z5 possessed highest intensity. Meanwhile, PT-Z5-B displayed restricted unsaturated polyaromatics peak compared with PT-Z5 and PT-Z5, indicating that highly-condensed polyaromatics, which could be easier induced for coke formation, were significantly suppressed over the external surface on boron-modified zeolite modified via impregnation method. For PT-Z5 and B-PT-Z5, slightly lower intensity for polyalkylated benzenes and unsaturated polyaromatics was observed for B-PT-Z5, which could be attributed to the coke formation in the intersection site, also indicating that alkylation of aromatics and hydrogen transfer was inhibited because of the suppressed total acidity. Actually, the highly condensed coke featured by polyaromatic rings, which mainly located over zeolite external surface, could be generated following the evolution path illustrated in Scheme 2. Ethylene could be adsorbed on an acid site and undergo several times of dimerization to form oligomerized carbocations. Besides, cracking process of higher olefinic oligomers could form lighter olefins with odd carbon atom, which could further participate in the oligomerization process to generate isolefins with odd carbon number [12]. Light aromatics could be formed subsequently through cyclization, which produced naphthenes, and hydrogen transfer (or dehydrogenation) process with another olefin molecular, thereby paving for the dual-cycle hydrocarbon pool mechanism including the alkene cycle and arene cycle (Scheme 2) [18]. Therefore, light aromatics with less side chains could form inside the zeolite pores and diffuse to the zeolite external surface, where external BAS accelerated the alkylation of light aromatics to polyalkylbenzene, which further underwent cyclization and hydrogen transfer and generate unsaturated polyaromatics or even graphite like coke over external surface. For PT-Z5, high external BAS content forced large amount of polyalkylated aromatics and polyaromatics production and accelerate coke formation over external surface. For B-PT-Z5, high fraction of Alpair in intersection site ensured the preference of arene cycle, thereby generating more light aromatics and internal polyaromatics coke. Despite lower total acidity for B-PT-Z5, the high external BAS fraction also contributed to the potential highly condensed coke formation. For PT-Z5-B, highest oligomeric unsaturated hydrocarbons peak was observed with gradual decrease during the test, indicating its transformation to light aromatics. Besides, lowest intensity for polyalkylated benzenes and highly unsaturated polyaromatics was detected, suggesting that the conversion of light aromatics to coke species was significantly suppressed, probably because of the lowest external BAS fraction in PT-Z5-B. 3.5 Co-deactivation pattern of the tandem catalyst The CO2 conversion loss for PT-Z5 an PT-Z5-B during the stability test displayed significant discrepancy, indicating the different deactivation extent of the iron-based catalyst combining with different zeolites. In order to get deep insight into the interaction of coke deposition between two components in the tandem catalyst, several characterizations were first implemented for the spent iron-based catalysts combining with PT-Z5 and PT-Z5-B after the stability test to detect the nature of coke deposition, which were denoted as SP-PT(Fe) and SP-PT-B(Fe). Besides, sole Fe-based was also applied for the 120 h CO2 conversion test and the spent catalyst was denoted as SP-Fe. Before the characterizations, the deactivated catalysts were tested for CO2 hydrogenation under the same condition (Figure S12). SP-Fe exhibited highest CO2 conversion and C5+ hydrocarbons selectivity, followed by SP-PT-B(Fe) and SP-PT (Fe), indicating the same trend for catalyst deactivation extent. Fig. 11 a displayed the TG analysis of the spent iron-based catalysts. The spectra presented sequential weight increase and loss along with the temperature increase. The weight increase was due to the oxidation of iron carbides and low valence FeOx species, while the weight loss at higher temperature was attributed to the combustion of carbon deposits. SP-PT(Fe) exhibited highest weight loss for coke combustion and lowest weight increase, indicating the highest coke amount over the Fe-based catalyst, followed by SP-PT-B(Fe) and SP-Fe, which could also be observed over C 1 s XPS spectra (Fig. 11 c) of spent iron oxides. These results highly agreed with the CO2 hydrogenation test. Besides, Fig. 11 b presented the FT-IR spectra of the spent oxides. The peak at 1100 cm−1 particularly represented the -CH3 functional group in linear alkanes [48], reflecting the existence of aliphatic coke over iron-based catalyst, which was considered to be generated by excessive C-C coupling through FTS, and would inflict restricted deactivation to the iron-based catalyst compared with aromatic coke, especially for the linear alkanes. Besides, peaks at 1430 cm−1 and 860 cm−1 were attributed to the aromatic rings and the C-H bond in aromatic hydrocarbons, surprisingly reflected the existence of aromatic coke on the iron-based catalyst [45,48]. SP-PT(Fe) displayed both highest intensity for aliphatic and aromatic type coke. For SP-PT-B(Fe), nevertheless, the peak for aromatic coke almost completely disappeared in spite of the strong peak for aliphatic coke next only to SP-PT(Fe). For SP-Fe, however, both type of coke was significant decrease, also suggesting the lowest coke amount formed without the existence of zeolites. Thus, it could be inferred that the existence of zeolites induced the formation of aromatics coke over iron-based catalysts. In addition, Fig. 11 d illustrated the Raman spectra of spent oxides. Two area denoted as D and G band was signed, representing H-containing disordered coke and more condensed graphite like coke [49]. The G bands displayed highest intensity for SP-PT(Fe), followed by SP-PT-B(Fe) and SP-Fe, indicating the most severe deactivation caused by graphite-like coke deposition over SP-PT(Fe), fitting well with the fastest CO2 conversion loss speed in the stability test. Actually, aromatic coke could hardly be produced or anchored over iron oxide due to the unrestricted growth of carbon chain in the FTS reaction, compared with the shape selective catalysis ability over HZSM-5. This could be confirmed by the disappearance and inhibition of aromatics-type coke and graphite like coke in SP-Fe. In addition, significant loss of graphite like coke in SP-PT-B(Fe) compared with SP-PT(Fe) also inferred that aromatics species diffusing from zeolites may influence the coking performance over iron-based catalyst, Thus, it could be deduced that the appearance of highly condensed coke over iron-based catalyst was realized with the assistance from the zeolites. In order to further confirm the aforementioned conclusion, specific types of carbon deposits over spent iron-oxides were studied by corrosion and extraction of spent oxides, followed by the detection by GC-MS. The results were illustrated in Fig. 12 a-c and the relevant soluble hydrocarbons were summarized in Table S9. It should be mentioned that GC-MS analysis for coke depositions extracted by CH2Cl2 was restricted by the insoluble coke with more condensed nature [40]. SP-Fe was abundant of long chain aliphatic hydrocarbons coke such as 2,4-dimethyl-heptane, 3,7-dimethyl-decane and hydrocarbons with more carbon number, without any aromatics detected. However, for those iron catalysts combined with zeolites, aromatics with significant intensity compared with aliphatic hydrocarbons were observed, indicating that the aromatics derived from zeolites occupied greater proportion in coke deposition than aliphatic hydrocarbons generated from FTS. For SP-PT(Fe), 1,3-diethyl-5-methyl-benzene with longer and more branched chains was obtained as the main soluble coke compared with 2,4-dimethyl-benzene in SP-PT-B(Fe). Combining with In-situ Drifts indicating that PT-Z5-B strongly inhibited the alkylation on the external surface, we speculated that the light aromatics generated from the zeolites could transfer to the surface of iron-based catalyst, while PT-Z5-B with suppressed external BAS constrained the overalkylation, generating lighter aromatics, as confirmed by the GC-MS results. Sole iron-based catalyst underwent common aliphatic coking through FTS, generating long chain hydrocarbons (Fig. 12 d). While for those combined with zeolites, the aromatic hydrocarbons could further participate in the coking process, generating aromatic coke and more condensed graphite coke (Fig. 12 e). In addition, PT-Z5-B possessing inhibited surface BAS donated lighter aromatics compared with PT-Z5. The latter providing more polyalkylbenzenes could further accelerate the formation of highly-condensed polyaromatics and graphite-like coke with faster process, compared with the former, as depicted in Fig. 12 f. Thereby, iron-based catalyst suffered from more severe deactivation over SP-PT(Fe), resulting in the faster CO2 conversion losing speed compared with SP-PT-B(Fe) (Fig. 7 b, d). In summary, boron modification could not only alleviate the condensed coke formation over zeolite surface, but also weaken the co-deactivation effect on the iron-based catalyst, thus enhancing the stability of the tandem catalyst. 4 Conclusion In this study, iron-based catalyst was mixed with boron modified phase transfer HZSM-5 zeolite with different methods. The element distribution-acidity-coke-stability relationship over boron-modified zeolite was proposed. It was found that boron pre-treatment could alleviate external and total strong BAS at similar degree, leading to reduced coke amount. While the increased Alpair fraction in the intersection site led to increased aromatics selectivity at initial stage with increased content of polyaromatics coke inside zeolite pores, causing quick aromatics selectivity loss induced by internal coking. Post treatment of boron species significantly decreased the surface strong BAS content, leading to inhibited formation of external condensed coke and passivating the overalkylation of light aromatics, ensuing highest BTEX selectivity. While post-treatment significantly reduced strong external BAS and inhibited formation of condensed external coke. Afterwards, the mechanism of olefins aromatization was studied and found that PT-Z5-B greatly suppressed the transformation of aromatics to polyalkylaromatics and polyaromatics. Combining with the GS-MS and coke analysis over spent iron oxides, it was found that aromatics generated from the zeolites could transfer to the surface of iron-based catalyst, which could further participate in the coking process over iron oxides, generating aromatic coke and more condensed graphite coke, contributing to fast deactivation over iron-based catalyst. This process could be slowed down by post-treatment of boron over the zeolites by delivering lighter aromatics from zeolite oxide. This study widened the cognition of co-deactivation pattern in OX-ZEO tandem catalyst and proposed effective methods for enhancing catalyst stability, providing new strategy for the future design of industrial catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation. coredata.dc:description: Carbon dioxide (CO2) hydrogenation to aromatics is promising for reducing the burden of petroleum fuels. Herein, iron-based catalyst was mixed with boron modified HZSM-5 with pre-treatment and post-treatment method. The textural, acidic and element distribution properties over zeolite framework and external surface were studied. Combining with characterizations for internal and external coke, the element distribution-acidity-coke-stability relationship over boron-modified zeolite was put forward. Pre-treated zeolite witnessed reduced amount of external and total Brönsted acid sites (BAS) with similar degree, and increase paired Al (Alpair) fraction in the intersection site, leading to increased aromatics selectivity and reduced coke amount. While boron post-treatment significantly reduced external surface BAS and inhibited formation of condensed external coke. Afterwards, the mechanism of olefins aromatization was studied and found that PT-Z5-B greatly suppressed the overalkylation of light aromatics, thus alleviating the co-deactivation pattern generated by transformation of coke precursors from zeolite to iron-based catalyst.
